awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Biological tuning of plasma membrane mixing
awd_abstract_narration:
All animal cells are surrounded by a plasma membrane that defines the outer surface of the cell.  Cells control the protein and lipid composition of their plasma membrane to support a broad range of functions, including acting as a sensor of the local cellular environment. For example, the plasma membrane senses and communicates to the cell interior when it is appropriate to grow and divide, if and where the cell should crawl, or when certain compounds or classes of compounds are present in the vicinity. This project will investigate how and why cells adapt their plasma membrane composition in response to several changes in their growth conditions. Many of these sensing functions are thought to depend on how proteins and lipids are organized within the plasma membrane, and the researchers will investigate how both membrane heterogeneity and sensing functions are impacted as cells adjust membrane composition. The long term goals of the project are to discover how cells maintain a heterogeneous membrane, and how this membrane structure contributes to the efficient functioning of the cell. The researchers will communicate their findings through publications, conference presentations, public lectures, development of undergraduate curricula, and outreach to high school students from backgrounds that are under-represented in the physical sciences.  The principle investigator will train undergraduate and graduate students for careers in STEM fields.

Plasma membranes isolated from intact cells separate into two liquid phases when cooled below room temperature, similar to oil and water in three dimensions. The presence of this phase transition at low temperature predicts the existence of smaller membrane domains at the higher temperatures where cells live in culture. The objective of the research is to directly observe domains in intact cells at growth temperature, and to determine if cells tune their membrane composition to control the physical properties of these domains in order to optimize cellular functions. The research will use conventional cell biological, biochemical, and biophysical techniques as well as cutting edge experimental methods, including super-resolution fluorescence localization microscopy to image the nano-scale organization of membrane components and quantitative lipidomics to detail plasma membrane lipid composition.

por.por_cntn:
Animal cells are bounded by a plasma membrane made up of proteins and lipids that control how cells sense and interact with their local environment.  Plasma membranes isolated from intact cells separate into two liquid phases when cooled below room temperature, similar to oil and water in three dimensions. The presence of this phase transition at low temperature predicts the existence of smaller membrane domains at the higher temperatures where cells live in culture.  Proximity to this phase transition also endows plasma membranes with the remarkable ability to adapt its local composition in response to forces acting on the membrane plane.  This project directly observed these and other impacts of the phase transition on both cellular and isolated membranes.  This project also supported work to improve and characterize super-resolution fluorescence localization microscopy images.  This project also provided opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to be engaged in research activities, contributed to the development of curriculum, and supported the PIs efforts to mentor and support diverse trainees within the biophysics field broad broadly.

This grant contributed to 16 peer reviewed publications, including 5 review articles and commentaries and 11 primary research papers.  One line of investigation focused on how the membrane phase transition contributes to the sorting of proteins with respect to receptors in immune cells.  It was shown that clustering receptors with soluble ligands or ligands presented on a fluid surface led to the assembly of a membrane domain that could sort other membrane proteins.  Several of the proteins investigated are involved in regulating immune receptor activation, suggesting a mechanism for receptor activation, and perturbations of the membrane phase transition had predictable and measurable impacts on the magnitude of signaling.  A second line of investigation explored roles for the membrane phase transition in cellular differentiation and in controlling the activity of cholesterol, a major component of the plasma membrane.  A last line of investigation included several projects to quantify the localization of proteins in both living and chemically fixed cells, and to improve and characterize the resolution of single molecule fluorescence localization images. 

This work has broad impact because establishes new modes of membrane organization and function that are expected to apply to a broad range of sensing processes at the plasma membrane of animal cells. In addition, this project provided research experiences for more than 15 undergraduate students in addition to graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.  This project also supported the PIs development of new curricula and supported her efforts to enhance the exposure and support of LGBTQA+ scientists in biophysics.
